en.value: Talking about daily housework and other activities - Present perfect, verbs "to do" vs. "to make"
It's your turn to wash up!
Can you help me do the laundry?
We need to fix the washing machine.
In this unit we are going to learn some phrases about chores and activities we do around the house. We will learn phrases like:
Memorise the word(s) and listen to the example.
When we do laundry, we can also say that we are "doing the washing" or that we "put a wash on". In the US you may hear people say that they "put a load in". All of them mean the same thing!
to do the laundry/to do the washing
You need to do this if your clothes are clean.
You need to do this if your clothes are dirty.
What should you do if your bed is untidy?
You still haven't taken out the rubbish!
In the US, we are more likely to hear the word "trash" instead of "rubbish". We may also say "to take out the recycling" if we are talking about separated rubbish.
Did he vacuum under the bed?

You may hear some different words when it comes to cleaning the floor. If you hear "to sweep", that means cleaning the floor with a broom. If you hear "to mop", it means cleaning the floor with a wet soapy mop.
It's your turn to do the housework!
Select the activity that describes a way of cleaning the floor.
This phrase can refer to a variety of activities.
I've done most of the washing up.
Have you fixed the shower yet?
If you have a pet, you need to do this.
Select the activity that you need to do if something is broken.
What needs to be done when the sink is full of dirty dishes?
Ask your roommate to give the dog some food.
Tom, can you [k]feed[/k] the dog please?
How could your roommate ask you to clean the dust off the floor?
Could you vacuum when you get back?
Could you make the bed when you get back?
Could you fix the floors when you get back?
We mean all household chores when we say this.
Put the words in the correct order to say that you are doing laundry.
Select the correct words to fill the gaps.
I will [k]fix[/k] the sink before [k]washing[/k] up.
Your roommate wants you to empty the bin. What do they say?
Could you take out the recycling please?
Could you put some rubbish in?
Could you mix up the trash and the recycling?
Put the words in the correct order to say you need to tidy your bed.
Listen to the audio. Which statement is correct?
Peter has to make his bed and take out the rubbish.
Peter has to take the rubbish that is under his bed.
Peter has to make his bed because it looks like rubbish.
Fill in the gap using the image.
Fill in the gaps with the correct letters.
Fill in the gap using the audio.
We need to [k]vacuum[/k] the whole flat.
Fill in the gap using the hint.
Martha doesn't like doing housework, but she does the washing up.
Martha doesn't do any housework because she doesn't like it.
Martha likes doing the washing up and other housework.
Do you have any [k]laundry[/k] to do?
We have a lot of [k]housework[/k] to do.
The activities and chores you have to do around the house.
Some people find housework a drag, while others find it relaxing. Tell us about the chores you can't stand, those you don't mind and - perhaps - the jobs you secretly love!
do the laundy / make the bed / take out the recycling / do the washing up
Time for our next past tense: the present perfect

Now let's look at the present perfect tense. Don't be fooled by its name! This is still a past tense, and in this unit you'll learn how and when to use it. In some languages, there is no difference between the past simple and the present perfect, but in English, we use both and it's important to understand the difference between them.
Past simple: I made the dinner.
Past continuous: I was making the dinner.
Select the sentence in the present perfect tense.

We can use the present perfect tense to talk about completed actions in the past, which still have some kind of connection with or impact on the present. Look at the two examples below. Each of them make us think about the past and the present at the same time.
I have done the dishes. = The dishes are clean now.
He has laid the table. = The plates are on the table now.
This sentence contains a past action which has an effect on the present.

We'll see a few uses of the present perfect tense in this lesson, but we'll look more closely at when to use it later. For now, let's focus on recognising it and forming it. Recognising it is fairly easy: it contains the verb "to have", followed by the main verb. As we have seen before, we can use a shortened form of the verb "to have".
He has gone shopping. = He's gone shopping.
They have made dinner for us. = They've made dinner for us.
Select the verb "to have" in each sentence.
She [h]has[/h] made a cup of coffee for you.
Select the main verb in each sentence.
This sentence is in the present perfect tense.
I took out the rubbish yesterday.
We almost always use the past simple with the word "yesterday".
They have gone to buy groceries.
They were going to buy groceries.
Select the two words that form the present perfect tense in each sentence.

As we now know, we form the present perfect tense with two verbs: the verb "to have", followed by a past participle (a form of the main verb). The verb "to have" changes depending on who is doing the action, but the past participle stays the same.
She [k]has[/k] gone to the grocery store.
Select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.

The past participle is not always the same as the past simple form of a verb. There are some patterns in how we form them, but in practice it's best to simply learn and memorise each one. Here are the past simple forms and past participles of a few useful verbs for you to compare.
The present perfect structure is to have + past participle.
He has (verb "to have") cooked (past participle) dinner for me.

To form a negative sentence in the present perfect, we add the word "not" after the verb "to have". To form a question, we swap the person / thing who has done the action with the verb "to have". We can also add a wh-question word / phrase to the beginning to ask different kinds of question.
Positive sentence: You have bought the groceries for dinner.
Negative sentence: You have not bought the groceries for dinner. / You haven't bought groceries for dinner.
Question: Have you bought the groceries for dinner?
Question: Where have you been? I was looking for you.
Select the words in the correct order.
[k]We haven't gone|We have not gone[/k] on holiday this year.
She [k]has not|hasn't[/k] tidied her room yet.
[k]They've done|They have done[/k] the dishes already.
Grammar: To do vs. to make

These verbs are fairly similar in meaning. Many languages use the same verb for both, and so they are often confused. However, in English, they are not synonyms. Let's take a look at how they differ in meaning. Don't forget to look at the examples, they will help you understand when to use "to do" and when to use "to make".
We generally use the verb "to do" when talking about jobs, work and other, more general, everyday tasks.
You did the dishes last night, so it's my turn.
This sentence talks about an everyday task.
I did all the housework today.
We also use "to do" for more general activities. That is to say, when we are not being very specific about exactly what it is that we are doing, we use "to do".
Listen and select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
As well as talking about everyday and general activities, there are lots of other expressions that only use "to do". Here are some of the most common ones:

We mainly use "to make" when talking about things that we construct or create, and when we are talking about meals and drinks that we prepare (however, sometimes we can also use "to do" colloquially when talking about food).
She made a new shirt from some old fabric.
What are you doing for dinner?
Select the word which CANNOT fill the gap: "What are you ... for lunch?"
There are also lots of expressions that we can only use with "to make". Here are some common ones:
Complete the sentence with "to do" or "to make".
Complete the sentence with "to do" or "to make" in the past simple.
She [k]did[/k] well in her English test.
I [k]made[/k] a mistake in my maths exam.
Complete the sentence with "to do" or "to make" in the present simple.
